item.question:
On a Red Hat 5 system, which of the following commands can you use to update the package bind to the latest available version?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You started an application (myapp) in the foreground.
How do you push this running application into the background without restarting the application?
item.choice: It is not possible without restarting the application.
item.hint: An application running in the foreground is able to receive signals using key combinations through a terminal. An application running in the background is not.

item.question: Which of the following can be used to switch your system to run level 1?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which runlevels should you NOT select as default runlevel in /etc/inittab?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: The question is not about which runlevels are actually used on a Linux system. The question asks which runlevels you should NOT select in order to get a workable running system.

item.question: Which command will display a list with all installed RPMs?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands would return all lines that contains text between brackets (i.e. [...])?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character, but within brackets means a literal dot. The backslash escapes the next character which means it loses it special meaning, if any, and will be considered literally.

item.question:
During installation of the package atop you encountered an error.
Which command will display the package status?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Consider the above piece of code that uses tabs to indent lines.
Which command will easily convert the tabs to 8 spaces?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are looking for an executable file foo.
Select TWO commands that would search for foo within directories set in the shell variable $PATH.
item.hint: You are required to provide TWO answers. So select two, no more, no less. The question asks for an executable file, not just any file named <font face="monospace">foo</font>.

item.question:
Suppose you know that an application atop is installed on the current system.
You have examined the man and info pages for atop thoroughly.
However, you still have an appetite for more information about atop.
Which of the following directories is the BEST first place to look for further documentation files?
item.hint: The question could be rephrased as: What is the default location for documentation files?

item.question: Which command will set the the default permissions for new files to <font face="monospace">rw-r-----</font>, regardless of the current setting?
item.hint: Beware that using the numeric notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should block. Using the symbolic notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should let through.

item.question: Which of the following commands enables write access to the file /usr/share/doc/lpi303/test for users who belong to the group of the file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to update a tar-archive you previously made.
Which option for the command tar best performs the given task?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the default signal the <font face="monospace">kill</font> command sends to a process when the signal is not specified?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will display the file /etc/hosts on standard output with all instances of 1 replaced by 2?.
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You received an ASCII file from a good friend of yours who uses the windows OS.
You notice that you see a lot of CR-LF line endings in the file.
How can you remove the CR part from the file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
On a system that has the above uptime.
Which command is best used to print out system boot messages?
item.hint: The kernel keeps the messages in a buffer in memory. This buffer is limited and when full messages are removed using a first in first out algorithm.

item.question: Which command line can be used to restart a running Linux system immediately?
item.hint: The question clearly states the system should restart IMMEDIATELY.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will create an ext3 filesystem on device /dev/sdb3?
Select TWO answers.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which RPM command displays all files belonging to package <font face="monospace">foo</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: How would you set the sticky bit on a directory?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to use vi-like editing commands at the bash command line editor.
However, the default bash settings enable emacs-like keystrokes.
How do you enable bash to recognize vi-like keystrokes?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which commands would check the integrity of an ext2 filesystem?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to examine kernel bootup messages after boot time?
item.hint: Some questions allow multiple answers. Sometimes the question will state how many correct answers are required, in this case not. If you do not know the answer immediately the best strategy is eliminating the answers you know are wrong and select the best answer from the ones that are left. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question. You can always come back to this question later on.

item.question:
If your system is running in runlevel 2 what best describes this runlevel on
a RedHat system?

item.question: What is the mountpoint of the first swap partition?

item.question:
You have setup quota-support for the home-directories.
Which command allows the sysadmin to set quotas for a specific user?

item.question: Which command can be used to determine the available space on all mounted partitions?

item.question:
What would be the correct command to remove the package atop completely from a Debian system?
Select two.
item.hint: By default removing a package under Debian will not remove the configuration files as well.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
What is the most probable value of the umask set for user guru0?
item.hint: With <font face="monospace">umask</font> you can specify the mask numerically or symbolically. When the mask is in numeric form it specifies what is blocked.

item.question: Which command would you use to display how many inodes are available on the <font face="monospace">/home</font> filesystem?
item.hint: The answers only cover the commands <font face="monospace">du</font> and <font face="monospace">df</font>. So choosing the correct command gets you halfway. You will then only need to remember if the command requires an option or not to show the amount of available inodes.

item.question: On a Debian system, which command will list all installed packages?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is a disadvantage of using symbolic links over hard links?
item.choice: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
A symbolic link can span different filesystems
The hard link uses the same inode as the original file, where a symbolic link has its own inode.
Removing a symbolic link does not remove the underlying file.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
item.hint: Although you personally might find more than one of the choices a disadvantage, the question is actually which of the following is the most disadvantage.

item.question:
Which command would allow you to remove a file on a filesystem without actually mounting it?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Assume your current working directory is ~ and you wish to copy the files from the homedirectory of user guru1 to the directory temp in your homedirectory.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following syslog-priorities represents the highest level of importance?

You want to move all directories and ONLY directories in you current working directory that start with test to the directory testing.
Which of the following commands would be best to perform this task?
item.hint: The question states you want to MOVE the directories which means you can eliminate one answer immediately. The question also states you want to move ONLY directories which eliminates another answer. Now you are left with two possible answers and it comes down to knowing if the command requires an option or not.

item.question:
You plugged in a USB DVDROM drive. The dmesg command told you it was detected as device /dev/sr0.
There is no fstab-entry for this device in /etc/fstab.
Which of the following commands can you use to mount the media in that drive to the (existing) directory /mnt/dvdrom?
item.hint: Many questions require you to know which options a command accepts and in which order. This can be very hard to memorize and you may find it difficult to choose between two answers that only differ in the order of their arguments. Fortunately, you can always come back to this question later on. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question.

item.question:
You want to repeat the last command you executed.
How would you do this?
item.hint: When the shell version is not stated explicitly always assume the question is about Bash.

item.question: What is the devicefile of the first primary partition on the second SCSI-harddisk?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to show all shell-variables?
item.hint: The Bash shell treats all variables equal but some are more equal than others. The most equal variables are exported to its children and the others are not. The question is about showing ALL variables, so not only the exported ones.

item.question: What option will allow a normal user to mount a filesystem and have only the user that mounted the filesystem unmount it?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You enter a command (mycmd) in bash and want to redirect both standard output and standard error output to one file (mylog).
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: This is a tricky question. If you know your I/O redirection rules you will probably find one correct answer quickly. But there are actually two correct answers. Before the shell will fork and execute the command it will have rewritten the commandline and removed all special characters and words from the commandline. So the order may not be that important.

item.question:
You have added a sound card and suspect it might be conflicting with another device.
Therefore you check the file /proc/____________ to learn which IRQs are being used by other drivers loaded by the kernel.

A user calls claiming she gets an error message saying there is no space left on the device when creating a new file.
Which command would you use to verify the problem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following device names point to logical partitions?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Suppose that you know that a task deals with the general concept monitoring, but you are not certain what commands are available for monitoring.
Which of the following Linux command lines would be the BEST first step in finding out about available tools?
item.hint: Personally you may find more than one answer correct. The question asks for a first step so you should select a single answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will do the same as kill -s INT 3022.
Select all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a file?
item.choice: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
the file will be persistent in memory
the file can only be deleted by the owner or a user with root-privileges.
the file can never be deleted by a regular user
item.correct_answer: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
item.hint: Remember we are talking Linux here.

item.question:
You enabled quota support for users on the filesystem mounted on /extra.
Which file holds the current quotas for users?
item.hint: The quota system keeps its administration on the filesystem itself. Knowing that the question is about user quota support, you should be able to pick the correct answer.

item.question:
With the command __________ you can display a file in octal format.
Provide only the name of the command.
item.hint: The question asks for only the commandname so providing the path as well, even if correct, is considered a wrong answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands will replace all lower case characters with upper case characters?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The command '<font face="monospace">echo $?</font>' will give you what information?
item.choice: The process id of the current shell.
The process id of last executed command.
The exit status of the last executed background command.
The exit status of the last executed foreground command.
item.correct_answer: The exit status of the last executed foreground command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Where would you add a library path if the library is currently located in your homedirectory and only temporarily used?
item.choice: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
Add it to <font face="monospace">/etc/modprob.conf</font> and run <font face="monospace">ldconfig</font> afterwards to update the cache-file
Call the system administrator and have her add it to the correct location
item.correct_answer: Add it to the <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font> variable prior to running the command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commandlines allows you to cancel a previous issued <font face="monospace">shutdown</font> command?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You created a new filesystem on the first harddisk (sda) on its third partition which you will mount on /extra.
You now want to enable the quota system for users on this new filesystem.
Which of the following commands would you use to enable the quota-system and make it effective for users?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: add the mount option <font face="monospace">usrquota</font> to the <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> options column for
add the filesystem with mountpoint <font face="monospace">/extra</font> to <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>
item.correct_answer: add the mount option <font face="monospace">usrquota</font> to the <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font> options column for
add the filesystem with mountpoint <font face="monospace">/extra</font> to <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands is implemented as a bash shell-builtin?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to get the fourth line from a file.
Which of the following commands would you use?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file/directory usually has a sticky bit?
item.choice: Every file that needs to stay memory-resident.
item.hint: When the question mentions something in general you must assume how things are done in Debian or RedHat system or specified in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

item.question:
Which of the following Linux commands can be used to create backups of filesystems and directories?
Select all correct answers.
item.hint: Although the question asks you to select all correct answers it does not mean there are multiple correct answers. However, if there are more than one correct answers you will need to provide them all to get points for this question.
